abstract.p: Preview of Sydney Olympics taekwondo tournament; photo (M)

block.p: THIS SPORT originated as a self-defense art in Korea, where its name means ''the way of foot and fist.''

Unlike the non-Olympic sport of karate, which involves the hands 80 percent of the time, taekwondo is 80 percent feet. This is its first appearance as an Olympic medal sport after demonstration status in 1988 and 1992.
THIS SPORT originated as a self-defense art in Korea, where its name means ''the way of foot and fist.''

Unlike the non-Olympic sport of karate, which involves the hands 80 percent of the time, taekwondo is 80 percent feet. This is its first appearance as an Olympic medal sport after demonstration status in 1988 and 1992.

THE SETUP -- The 100 athletes from 48 nations will compete in four weight classes for men and four for women (normally in world championships, there are eight classes for each). A loss before the finals eliminates chances for a gold or silver, but anyone who loses to a finalist returns in a repechage, or second chance, tournament for a bronze medal.

THE SCORING -- Each match can last three rounds of three minutes each and ends in a knockout or decision. Points are scored with a kick or a punch to the colored portion of a padded chest protector or a kick to the helmet. Three judges score the match electronically. If the judges tie, the referee decides the winner.
THE STRATEGY -- As in chess matches, many competitors think defense first and pick moments to try to score. As a result, scores are often low, like 2-1 or 3-2.
THE NAMES -- The only countries to qualify the maximum of two men and two women are Korea, Chinese Taipei, the United States, the Philippines, Spain and Cuba.

The strongest favorite is Victor Estrada Garibay of Mexico in men's welterweight. Kay Poe, 18, of Houston is favored in women's flyweight, and medals seem likely from Juan Moreno of Miami in men's flyweight and Steven Lopez of Sugarland, Tex., in men's featherweight.
